title: 109_hr4959
content: The Act is titled the "Reciprocity and Fairness in Foreign Investment Act" and includes limitations on investment and certain operations by foreign entities. The "Reciprocity and Fairness in Foreign Investment Act" imposes limitations on foreign government-owned enterprises regarding acquiring equity interests in US businesses and real property, mirroring the restrictions imposed on US persons in the foreign country. Foreign persons can invest in critical infrastructure in the United States only to the extent that their home country allows US persons to do the same. Critical infrastructure refers to vital systems and assets that are essential to a country's functioning. The term "critical infrastructure" refers to vital systems and assets essential for a country's functioning, including airports, bridges, highways, railroads, ports, pipelines for oil and gas, and electricity facilities. The destruction of these systems would have a severe impact on a country's security, economy, or public health and safety. The term "foreign person" refers to a national of a foreign country, including entities organized under foreign laws or owned/controlled by individuals or entities from that country. The term "United States person" includes any United States citizen, entity organized under US laws, and owned or controlled by US citizens, State or local governments, or the United States. SEC. 3. ENFORCEMENT. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with other relevant departments, shall issue regulations to enforce section 2. Civil penalties of up to $500,000 may be imposed on foreign persons violating section 2. The Secretary of the Treasury has the authority to impose these penalties. Additionally, the Secretary may seek other relief through legal action in the United States district court. The Attorney General can take legal action in the United States district court to stop violations of section 2 or related regulations. They may also seek divestment relief to enforce the Act. The Secretary of the Treasury must issue an annual report on foreign countries' laws regarding investment by foreign persons in enterprises and real property, as well as control of critical infrastructure. The effective date of this requirement is specified. The Act will take effect 180 days after enactment, with exceptions for existing investments to allow foreign countries time to adjust their laws.
